ETYMOLOGY: From Old English æġhwæþer, compounded from ā 'ever' + ġehwæþer 'each of two' (from ġe- collective prefix + hwæþer 'which of two').

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word used to connect clauses or sentences or to coordinate words in the same clause.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Used before two or more alternatives to show that only one of them is possible.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 用于两个或多个选择之前，表示只能选择其中之一。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: You can either call me or send me an email.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 你可以给我打电话或者发邮件。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A modifying word that determines the kind of reference a noun or noun group has.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: One or the other of two people or things.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: There are two doors, and either door leads to the garden.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 有两扇门，任何一扇门都通向花园。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word that can function as a noun phrase referring to someone or something previously mentioned or known.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: One or the other of two things or people.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: （两者中）的任何一个；其中之一。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: You can choose either of these books.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 这两本书你可以任选一本。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word or phrase that modifies an adjective, verb, or other adverb or a word group, expressing a relation of place, time, circumstance, manner, cause, degree, etc.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Used after a negative statement to indicate that the statement also applies to something else.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: If you don't go, I won't go either.

REGISTER: Formal and informal speech and writing.
